In Pictures | Tottenham's Toby Alderweireld 1/11 
Toby Alderweireld's Tottenham career in pictures... BEN STANSALL/AFP/Getty Images 2/11 
Toby Alderweireld makes his debut for Tottenham, playing 64 minutes in a 2-1 pre-season friendly loss to MLS All-Stars on July 29, 2015. Doug Pensinger/Getty Images 3/11 
Tody Alderweireld made his Premier League debut for Tottenham in a 1-0 loss to Manchester United at Old Trafford on August 8, 2015. Matthew Peters/Man Utd via Getty Images 4/11 
Toby Alderweireld scored his first goal for Tottenham to put his side in the lead as Manchester City were beaten 4-1 at White Hart Lane on September 26, 2015. Julian Finney/Getty Images 5/11 
Another goal in a big game came on March 5, 2016, as Toby Alderweireld equalised for Tottenham against Arsenal at White Hart Lane. Tottenham Hotspur FC via Getty Images 6/11 
Toby Alderweireld was also on target against Manchester United, scoring the second as Tottenham ran out 3-0 winners at White Hart Lane on April 10, 2015. Julian Finney/Getty Images 7/11 
Toby Alderweireld's fine debut season with Tottenham earned him a PFA Player of the Year nomination, along with team-mates Danny Rose, Dele Alli and Harry Kane, a place in the PFA Team of the Year and being crowned Tottenham's Player of the Year. Julian Finney/Getty Images 8/11 
Toby Alderweireld scored Tottenham's first Champions League goal in over six and a half years with a header against Monaco on September 14, 2016. BEN STANSALL/AFP/Getty Images 9/11 
Toby Alderweireld suffered a knee injury during a 1-1 draw with West Brom on October 15, 2016, which kept him sidelined for almost two months. Michael Regan/Getty Images 10/11 
Toby Alderweireld shares a joke in training with Tottenham and Belgium team-mate Mousa Dembele on February 14, 2017. Tottenham Hotspur FC via Getty Images 11/11 
Toby Alderweireld in action for Tottenham against former club Southampton on March 19, 2017. JUSTIN TALLIS/AFP/Getty Images 
Toby Alderweireld is seeking a new contract to put him in line with Tottenham ’s top earners, Harry Kane and Hugo Lloris . 
Spurs are keen to agree a deal for the centre-half after details of his current contract were leaked late last year, including a £25million release clause that would become active in summer 2019, when the Belgian will be 30. 
Alderweireld is the only key first-team player who has not signed an extension since the start of 2016 - with the exception of Victor Wanyama who has been at Spurs for just nine months. 
Alderweireld’s deal, worth about £50,000 a week, expires in two years but the club hold an option to prolong it until 2020. Spurs undecided whether to hire direct replacement for Paul Mitchell 
Both Kane and Lloris have deals that could earn them in excess of £100,000 per week, though Spurs say their basic salaries fall within the club’s wage structure. 
Recent history suggests that player and club will find common ground. It is very rare for Spurs to allow an important to player to drift into the final 18 months of his contract. 
Negotiations for Kane, Lloris and Christian Eriksen, who signed a new deal last September, took considerable time but, in the end, chairman Daniel Levy secured the signatures of all three. Yet it is likely Alderweireld would need a substantial pay rise to re-sign.
